column4: so I was intending on using putty to create a reverse ssh tunnel to my home ubuntu server, which in theory anyway, would allow me to use my windows system to rdp into my work computer
that's a pretty strange setup
it would work, yes, but ssh will make it slow
speed isn't really a concern to me. I would be working from home and moving at a slower pace anyway... more coffee breaks :)
when i set up a tunnel to SSH into a server and connect to the SOCKS proxy over ssh, i do: ssh desktop -L 1080:localhost:1080
in putty, config a "remote" tunnel or w/e they call it

yeah, i have all the docs on using putty to set it up, I was just wondering if it was going to be possible to get the remote (work) system to connect to my local server (ubuntu) and use my local (windows) system to rdp back thru the ubuntu server into the windows system
once you have putty connected with the remote "forward", on the remote system sshd shuold be listening on the RDP port
here's a good description, but it's going the other way for you: http://souptonuts.sourceforge.net/sshtips.htm
as long as you can connect to the ssh server now, adding a forward to it should not be an issue
i use forwarding at school because the only unfiltered port is 443 (they can't proxy ssl) so i have my server listen on 443 for ssh, and i connect to that with port 1080 forwarding
then i tell GNOME to connect to localhost:1080 for a SOCKS
right, and by default sshd will only bind to localhost:rdp
you need to reconfig sshd to let remote forwards bind to 0.0.0.0:rdp
and where in the sshd_config is that?
so you can only use the forward from that sshd server by default. i know this from when i used remote forwards to host a webcam image server from an airport via my VPS
